Award.AwardTitle: Student Support for the 8th Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics (ACM BCB 2017)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 8th ACM International Conference on Bioinformatics and Computational Biology and Health Informatics (ACMBCB2017) is the flagship conference of the ACM SIGBio (Special Interest Group in Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics) to be held in Boston, MA, August 20-23, 2017. It is the premier dissemination forum for interdisciplinary research linking computer science, mathematics, statistics, biology, bioinformatics, biomedical informatics, and health informatics. Its mission is to support advanced research, training, and outreach. It brings together leading researchers, practitioners, and students around the world to promote novel scientific findings in bioscience and to deliver new knowledge for societal impact. The past few decades have seen tremendous growth in the scale and complexity of biological and medical data including recent mainstream recognition of big data challenges. However, the development of synergy in bioinformatics, computational biology, and biomedical informatics research has been difficult. Thus, it is important to cultivate the new culture when training younger generations. This NSF grant will provide support to about 20 top junior U.S.-based professionals (students and recently graduated post-doctoral fellows) to participate in the conference. In addition, because women and underrepresented minority groups have relatively low participation in Bioinformatics and Computational Biology (BCB), ACMBCB2017 will expand its "Women in Bioinformatics" organization to strongly encourage participation from women and other underrepresented junior researchers. Two senior professionals will be invited to share their experience and wisdom in career development, and to serve as mentors to facilitate young professional groups with the goal to continually build the community throughout the year. The goal of these activities is to increase the participation of junior researchers; train the next generation of researchers and educators in computer science, biological science, biomedical science and other related areas; broaden the diversity from underrepresented groups in BCB; and provide mentorship by senior researchers serve to young professionals to improve bioinformatics, computational biology, and health informatics community building in ACM SIGBio.

The ACMBCB2017 conference will showcase leading-edge research on new technologies and techniques around gathering, processing, analyzing, and modeling of data and information for a variety of scientific, clinical, and healthcare applications, from bench to bedside. It will provide well planned and organized activities such as workshops, tutorials, oral sessions, and poster sessions for researchers from different disciplines to interact, to foster discussion and collaboration. The ACMBCB2017 materials, including contributions from the junior researchers (e.g., short research proposals and presentations) will be shared on website ACMBCB2017 (http://acm-bcb.org/2017/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the annual conference of ACM SIGBio, the ACM International Conference on Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, and Health Informatics (ACMBCB) aims (1) to provide an interactive forum for researchers, practitioners, and students from around the world to promote scientific understanding and findings in bioscience, and (2) to strengthen interdisciplinary research across computer science, mathematics, statistics, biology, bioinformatics, and biomedicine. As its flagship annual conference, ACMBCB2017 in Boston MA on Aug. 20-23, 2017, (http://acm-bcb.org/) provides researchers and practitioners a platform to bridge these important interdisciplinary research areas. While developing synergy of the research on bioinformatics, computational biology, and health informatics is not easy, it is particularly challenging for underrepresented (URM) groups (women, minority, and people with disabilities).  The goals of this ACMBCB2017 NSF project are to increase young professional participation (students and postdoctoral fellows who graduated during after Jan. 2017), and to broaden participation diversity in ACMBCB2017.

 

The first key outcome is all applicants wrote a research abstract with NSF-required “Intellectual Merit” and “Broad Impact” describing their key research Bioinformatics, Computational Biology, or Health Informatics beyond the research paper(s) or poster(s) submitted to ACMBCB2017. Also, awardees are provided PPT template to present their research in The Young Professional Research Forum. Among 33 undergrad, master, and PhD graduate students, post-docs, and newly graduated research scientists who submitted application packages, 20 were selected with one serving as the forum student co-chair. This forum had attracted ACMBCB2017 attendees in addition to the awardees, their advisors, mentors, and peers.  This NSF project broadened the participation of young professionals, and maximized their learning of advanced knowledge in bioinformatics, computational biology, and health informatics through the well-planned and organized conference activities, and advances their future research.

 

The second key outcome is as a requirement for receiving this NSF support, awardees attended the entire ACMBCB2017 (oral and poster sessions) conference. Thus, this NSF project enables young professionals to meet distinguished speakers, to present their own research ideas, to discuss any new research problems, and to foster new collaborations in the joint computing, biology, and health communities. It also enables established researchers in bioinformatics, computational biology, and health informatics to provide mentorship to the next generation young professionals to help cultivate the new interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary research field.

 

The third outcome on is on diversity. Two keynote speakers (Prof. Tandy Warnow, The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and Dagmar Ringe, Brandeis University), and two of research forum co-chairs are woman faculty. Among 20 awardees, there were nine (9) women. In addition, the PI has organized the Women-in-Bioinformatics panel with eight (8) experienced woman panelists from academics, industry, and government lab to share their insight on career development, and work-life balance.  Such high women participation is significantly higher than the average percentage of women in computing, and this is a unique highlight of ACMBCB2017.
